channel.title: tutte on Dave's Homepage
channel.description: Recent content in tutte on Dave's Homepage

item.title: Version 0.9.18
item.description: The following updates have been made: Updated code to eliminate C++ warnings and errors. Addresses issue on MacOS High Sierra.

item.title: Version 0.9.17
item.description: The following updates have been made: Added support for the --split-edges option. This allows splitting a graph based on the number of edges, rather than the number of vertices.

item.title: Version 0.9.16
item.description: The following updates have been made: Incorporated the vorder push heuristic suggested by Michael Monagan. As part of this, I’ve added the ability to sort the vertex order according to a depth-first or breadth-first search.

item.title: Version 0.9.15
item.description: The following updates have been made: For the --chromatic option, the tool now automatically removes multi-edges on the input graph. Thanks to Alan Sokal for pointing out this bug.

item.title: Version 0.9.14
item.description: The following updates have been made: Added better support for report statistical data on the operation of the cache. This is to help diagnosing cache behaviour, as there’s some interesting possibilities for optimising the caching strategies.

item.title: Computing Tutte Polynomials
item.description: Abstract: The Tutte polynomial of a graph is a 2-variable polynomial graph invariant of considerable importance in both combinatorics and statistical physics. It contains several other polynomial invariants, such as the chromatic polynomial and flow polynomial as partial evaluations, and various numerical invariants such as the number of spanning trees as complete evaluations.

item.title: Edge-Selection Heuristics for Computing Tutte Polynomials
item.description: Abstract. The Tutte polynomial of a graph, also known as the partition function of theq-statePotts model, is a 2-variable polynomial graph invariant of considerable importance in bothcombinatorics and statistical physics. It contains several other polynomial invariants, such asthe chromatic polynomial and flow polynomial as partial evaluations, and various numericalinvariants such as the number of spanning trees as complete evaluations.

item.title: Version 0.9.13
item.description: The following updates have been made: Version 0.9.12 introduced a feature whereby “large” graphs were never displaced from the cache. This was useful for us where we were computing the polynomial of the Truncated Icosahedron.

item.title: Version 0.9.12
item.description: The following updates have been made: A long standing bug related to memory corruption has been fixed. Support for 64bit machines now works correctly. This means you can use very large caches (e.

item.title: Edge-Selection Heuristics for Computing Tutte Polynomials
item.description: Abstract: The Tutte polynomial of a graph, also known as the partition function of the q-state Potts model, is a 2-variable polynomial graph invariant of considerable importance in both combinatorics and statistical physics.

item.title: Visualizing the computation tree of the Tutte Polynomial
Tutte Polynomials
item.description: Overview. Tutte polynomials play an important role in graph theory, combinatorics, matroid theory, knot theory, and experimental physics. For example, the polynomials can be evaluated to find the number of spanning trees in a graph, the number of forests in a graph, the number of connected spanning subgraphs, the number of spanning subgraphs, and the number of acyclic orientations.
